My advice to them would be to embrace their curiosity and creativity without fear of repercussions. Don't be afraid to take risks and experiment with different styles, genres, and mediums. 

For me, the process of remixing and repurposing existing works is not about copying or imitating, but about transforming and reinterpreting. It's about taking something familiar and turning it into something entirely new and original. I believe that this process can lead to innovative and thought-provoking art that challenges societal norms and sparks meaningful conversations.

When I started creating my own derivative works, I faced a lot of criticism and skepticism. People would say that I was infringing on copyrights, or that my work was not "original" enough. But I didn't let that discourage me. Instead, I used it as fuel to continue pushing the boundaries of what is considered "acceptable" in the art world.

My advice to emerging creators would be to develop a thick skin and be prepared for criticism. Not everyone will understand or appreciate your work, and that's okay. What's important is that you stay true to your vision and continue to create art that resonates with you and your audience.

It's also essential to understand the context and intentions behind your work. Be mindful of the cultural and historical significance of the original works you're remixing and repurposing. Be respectful, but also don't be afraid to challenge and subvert existing power dynamics.

Ultimately, the key to successful remixing and repurposing is to add value and meaning to the original work. Ask yourself, "What can I bring to the table that's new and innovative?" or "How can I use this existing work to tell a new story or convey a different message?" By doing so, you'll not only create something unique and original but also contribute to the ongoing conversation about the role of art in society.

Remember, the art world needs more innovators, risk-takers, and rule-breakers. Don't be afraid to challenge traditional boundaries and push the limits of what's possible. The future of art depends on it!
